_prev_prog_3.MH_OtherType: Various situations for all on site chemicals
_prev_prog_3.Description: DSM NeoResins Frankfort site has taken great care to ensure it has itentified potential hazards that could lead to a catastrophic incident and has many systems in place to prevnt such an incident. The following bullet points apply to all areas of the facility where any dangerous chemical is used. * 22 years of safe handling practices with Acrylonitrile with never a reportable incident. * Containment dikes, spill holding tanks and foam suppression system to mitigate any spills or emergencies. * Member of the local LEPC with regular visits and reviews by the local Fire Department. * Local Haz-mat team available for Fire Department. * Operators are trained on safe use practices and operation of plant equipment. * Redundant tank and facility equipment alarms and systems to control/prevent emergencies or incidents. *OSHA STAR site with good practices in place for safe operation. * Plant operators are Haz-woper trained to respond to plant emergencies. * Regular PM's completed as part of OSHA PSM program. * Alarms and prevention drills tested annually. We stive to continue to improve our safety systems and processes through a number of state of the art systems and industry best practices. We have completed Hazard Analysis of all plant processes and continue to review these Hazard Analysis on a set frequency to ensure continued compliance and safe operation.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
DSM Coating Resins Frankfort facility manufactures products that are sold in the paint and coatings industry. Acrylonitrile is a chemical used in the manufacture of thos products. The chemical is stored in an above ground tank inside a containment dike capible of holding the contents of the entire tank. The chemical is transferred into the manufacturing facility through steel pipes. Because of the amount of Acrylonitrile stored at the facility we are required to comply with the EPA's Risk Management program standard.



As required by the RMP standard our facility has developed a "Worse Case Scenario" to describe the possibility of a release and the impact to the community in the event of such and incident. DSM Coating Resins has completed community awareness meetings and includes the local LEPC in all communications or changes. The scenarios used to design the RMP were based on the EPA's OCA Guidance documents and look up tables. The Worse Case Scenario is based on and entire loss of the storage tank holding Acrylonitrile. It was assumed that the material was contained in the holding dike. The dike not only contains the entire spill, but limits the surface area and amount of evaporation. The impact of this type of release reaches and end point of 1.2 miles and includes industrial and residential receptors causing submission of the plan under program 3.



The results are also that we have 2 possible alternative scenarios. 



The first is an alternative scenario and deals with the release during and off laod of the chemical Acrylonitrile, because of the information from the guidance document the release differs form the Worse Case Scenario. This scenario has an impact of only .20 miles away and only includes industrial receptors. 



The second alternative scenario is based on a release of Acrylonitrile from the pipe that transfers the chemical from the storage tank to the process area. This scenario unlike the first alternate scenario does not have the chemical co

ntained and instead forms a pool on the ground. Because the quantity and release rate are much smaller than the Wrose Case and Alternate #1 scenarios the end point of the release is only 0.11 miles and includes no receptors. 



This facility is also required to follow the OSHA PSM standard and has completed Process Hazard Reviews required under that standard. The facility has organized and trained employees on the emergency response requirements for chemical spills and other safety related incidents. The facility has developed an Emergency Response plan and trains employees on this plan and any changes. The facility also works closely with the community LEPC and State Emergency Planning Commission to ensure good understanding and communication of any and all safety programs, chemicals and storage areas at the site.
